People will make this way too complex, but if you want the simple answer... Yes, its always a good idea to invest excess money into the market SP and you have two ways to do this Invest it all today. Invest it periodically, ranging from 624 months and invest an equal amount every month, e.g. invest 7,000 every month for 12 months straight. This has lower returns on average, but it has less risk as if the market crashes during that period you will benefit from being able to buy at lower prices. Youre probably wondering why theres no third option wait until the market declines and then invest, and the reason is because it doesnt work. Theres no way to predict markets no matter how much everyone likes to pretend there is. It may take a decade, and even if it happens tomorrow youre probably gonna be waiting until well past the bottom before you realize you missed your chance.

It depends. Say you have a car loan at 10, credit card balance at 25, and mortgage at 3. You could set the cutoff at 7, which is approximately the average return for the SP500, so you would pay off the car and credit card in full, only make the minimum payments on the mortgage, and invest the rest. The idea is that if you have low interest debts, that works in your favor by not paying it off and investing your money instead in a higher interest rate environment meaning, if you were to refinance a liability, you would get a worse rate than you have now. You could probably go as high as 10 as the cutoff and not pay off the car, and justify this by saying ok, the average return for the SP is actually going to go up due to the fed rate cycles from the last 10 years. Just remember, the higher you go, the riskier the strategy becomes, because it reduces the likelihood that your invested capital will outperform the rate of return your creditors are making by charging you interest. This would be a Robert Kiyosaki approach to building wealth, identifying where you are borrowing cheaply and continue to do so to free up capital to acquire assets which yield more than your liabilities take. The Dave Ramsey approach would be to eliminate all liabilities first and assume the minimum risk possible. This is the safest way, and result in maximum capital preservation, but lowest capital growth.

Cause when a business sends a transfer of right now it has to go through 2, 3, 4, or more people to get to its destination, and it seems incredibly inefficient and a waste of money for everyone but the middlemen because all theyre doing is confirming, recording, and sending it on.

Upon reflection, what they might be trying to get out is changing direct debit dates, which I have to say is an absolute faff. Most organisations only have particular dates you can have them on for example my council tax has to be on something like the 10th, 18th, or 28th of every month and some organisations dont let you change it at all so its purely based on when you signed up. If this solves that problem it would be hugely helpful for people like me who likes having everything come out on payday.
Cargo ships are often even cheaper than rail to transport goods. Depends on the route.

The problem is the middle men do add something in this case accountability. The difference between buying something with crypto with no middleman and buying something on a credit card is if there is fraud, I lose my crypto but Visa makes sure Im whole. I cant really imagine not using a credit card just for security reasons, the rewards are just a bonus.

MA is often middle men, disruptors, or smaller competitors being bought out by the big players. IIRC V and MC have absorbed quite a few smaller companies over the years. Where the middle man is providing a service that you may not be able to replicate inhouse, you leave it alone.

As the other guy said, Blockchain is a known tech and all banks have teams working on finding use cases for it The fact that it still hasnt materialised in any meaningful way says a lot Also, the middlemen are often forced by AML KYC laws. It would be a lot faster and cheaper if there werent any controls. Money launderers and terrorists would love it too

Looking at Berkshire as a whole, you need to take into account all of these assets and liabilities. Or are you asking about how a fund andor fund manager is able to buy and sell assets without worrying about taxes? If you are asking about the latter its because most funds are structured as RICs. A RIC is a tax efficient method so that doubletaxation doesnt occur. If you invest in a fund you own some portion of the fund. As the fund buyssells assets and has gains it becomes unfair to smaller retail investors who may have a lower taxable income bracket. RICs allow the taxes to be passed to the actual endinvestor instead so that smaller retail investors are not impacted by corporate taxes. And higher income investors in higher tax brackets are paying their tax share. And it avoids doubletaxation issues.

They absolutely do have to worry about these things. There are entire teams at large financial institutions that specialize in all sorts of niche technical tax matters. Many of the largest institutional investors think university endowments, foundations, pensions are taxexempt, which allows them to invest in strategies that would otherwise be too expensive from a tax perspective. Individual investors do have one way in which they can invest and not pay taxes on gains IRA accounts. replies.text: Someone owns a fraction of a company. They would rather have cash in their pocket. You buy it from them. Now you dont have that cash, but you do have a fraction of a company or with an ETF, smaller fractions of hundreds of companies, and you own a fraction the profits that company makes in the future. Generally, over time, those profits will exceed what you originally paid plus you can sell those shares to someone else at a maybe higher or lower price, like they sold to you.

Lets say you make 5000 a month. Of that, 2000 goes to rent and bills, and 2000 goes to other expenses like groceries and entertainment. This leaves you 1000 a month. At first you want to set aside that 1000 a month in your savings accounts exactly what youre doing until you have about 6 months of expenses saved up in case of emergency, which in this case would be 24,000. The money in your savings account will make a little bit of interest, but thats not an investment. Its more of a loan that youre making to the bank, and theyre giving you a little bit of money for the privilege holding your money. An investment is when you own something of value. You could invest in a car, but the value of that car would likely go down over the years. You could invest in a house, and the value of that house would likely go up over the years. The issue with these investments is that theyre not liquid meaning, you cant really do any much with the change in value. Your car may be worth half of its initial value in 5 years, but that doesnt make you any worse off. Your house could double in value after 10 years, but that doesnt mean you can take a trip to Cabo whenever you want. What most people refer to when they say they want to invest is they want to own part of a business, they want to share in the profits and losses of that business, and they want to be able to sell that part of a business that is, liquidate it to have more liquid money to take a trip to, say, Cabo. You could invest in your own business sink 100,000 into a commercial property that youre renting to clean up, design, and open up a restaurant. If this restaurant is successful, it may make 10,000 a month in profit. Now, you can do one of two things with this profit 1. You can withdraw it, put it in your own bank account and take a flight to Cabo this is called taking a dividend, but be aware that you have now decreased your restaurants value by 10,000 in order to increase your personal wealth by 10,000 2. Or you can use it to build out the patio of your restaurant to accommodate more customers and then make 15,000 a month in profit, so the value of your restaurant has now increased. Now, again, you can either take a dividend, or you can reinvest it into the growth of the company. But starting a restaurant takes a lot of upfront work. Whats a lot easier is buying a part ownership of an already existing business, like the graphics card company NVIDIA or the retail company Costco. If you buy a share of NVIDIA, you are entitled that tiny fraction of value of the company, but you should be aware that its NVIDIAs policy to reinvest its earnings, because its in a growth phase so the value of your shares grows, but you arent making money. If you buy a share of Costco, you are entitled that tiny fraction of value of the company, but you should be aware that Costco pays out dividends because its not in a growth phase so youre making money, while the value of your shares stays the same. Theres no wrong answer, theres just what you want to get out of investing. But what if NVIDIAs competitor AMD comes out with a new technology that absolutely crushes NVIDIA and causes their stock to tank? Its risky to own single stocks. So what you can do instead is buy a share of a mutual fund, which contains hundreds or even thousands of stocks. For example, with my personal excess savings I buy shares of VTSAX, which contains shares of all the publicly traded companies in the United States. It doesnt matter if a couple companies lose value, because Im confident that most companies in the US will be doing well and growing over the time horizon I plan to hold this mutual fund for a couple decades at least enough so to outweigh poorly performing companies. So if you want to invest in a mutual fund, open up an account with a brokerage firm, such as Vanguard, Schwab, or Fidelity, and set up your account to automatically withdraw a certain amount of money each month to buy a broadbased mutual fund like VTSAX or you can buy individual stocks like NVIDIA, or you can buy ETFs, which are somewhere in between. With VTSAX in particular, over the next few months youll see the value go up and down, over the next few years youll see its value go up slightly, and in 1020 years those mutual funds will be worth waaaay more than what you paid for them, so you can sell them and take a hundred flights to Cabo.

If it was just you buying a single stick on a platform like Robinhood or eTrade, then that was a bad company. If it was a 401k or something managed by a financial advisor, they scammed you. A few things you can do to greatly improve your chances Make sure anyone youre working with is a fiduciary. This is a legal term that means they must make decisions in your best interests. So called financial advisors who arent fiduciaries can and often do advise you to take steps that benefit their employers. This can be someone like actively managing your account by making changes even week or even several times every day and then charging a fee for each change they make without consulting you about those changes. Invest broadly, not with just one stock. Also, dont buy anything unless youre confident in that company for the next 10 years. They need to have an advantage that is hard to take away, like Apples strong brand loyalty or the near monopoly and extensive infrastructure that some companies have which takes a decade to catch up to. Keep inflation in mind. No matter what, a regular or high yield savings account will return to you less than what inflation eats away. So definitely keep an emergency fund in a high yield savings account. That makes it quickly available if bad things happen or a big expense comes up. Ive used mine for car down payments, proactively replacing a furnace, pet medical emergencies, etc. Keep at least 1,000 in theRe and ideally 36 months of expenses, depending on your level of worry. But those funds will always have less buying power the next year, because inflation will always be higher than the interest they offer, due to macroeconomic forces. So put the rest into other things. Try to use a well managed, tax advantaged account. Ask for the data about the accounts past performance for at least the time back through the last crisis. If you can see the total performance of the last 1520 years, do that. Get at least the last 7 or 10, though. That will help give an idea of whether it is decently managed or not. And ask about fees. It should be a very small fee, like less than 1. The tax advantaged part means a 403b for schools, hospitals, etc., a 401k corporate environment, IRA, or Roth IRA. In some cases, like with the 403b, the funds are taken from the paycheck before taxes are calculated and then taxes are applied when the funds are taken from the account after retirement. For illustration, Ill completely make up some numbers. Say you are paid 1,000 and taxes would have been 200 and you put 200 into a 403b. That means you get 200 in the account but then youre taxed on only 800. So your takehome is more like 640 instead of 800. You now have 200 403b 640 840 instead of 800. If the account is decent, that 200 gains interest over time and that interest isnt taxes, either. After you retire, lets say you pull 600 out of the account. That is taxed as if it was 600 in income. So you can control how much comes out of the account and when, allowing you some degree of control over how much youre taxed in retirement. Meanwhile, the account is fluctuating based on the market. You could convert it to an account that works like a pension, but the jargon gets detailed at that point and I dont fully understand it myself.. So, yes, the value going down at any moment is possible. However, over longer periods of time like 2 years it goes up faster than inflation. If youre doing this yourself, start simple. Get some index funds. If you look at a graph of the value of the SP500 over the last 10, 20, or 40 years, youll see the rough pattern that most broad index funds follow. Youll see that the line mostly goes up, with occasional dips of 0.5 to 3 years before it beats its old high. There is always a chance of it going to hell. It isnt insured with FDIC. This is why there are warnings about past performance doesnt guarantee future returns. So, yes, rush exists. But you can reduce that risk by working with a fiduciary, using a fund that has a good track record, keeping a big emergency fund in a HYSA, and using tax advantaged accounts. If thats not for you, thats absolutely your choice to make. Your experiences are real. Dont let some stranger on the Internet berate you for it. working with is a fiduciary. I wish people would stop saying that because its not true. At least its not true in the US. And it causes a lot of confusion. I know that in places like Canada there was issues with how the fiduciary rule works and terminology. In the US all investment advisers with an e are legally bound with a duty of care and duty of loyalty. That is the fiduciary duty that always exists. This includes Duty to provide advice that is in the best interest of the client Duty to seek best execution Duty to provide advice and monitoring over the course of the relationship All investment advisers in the US are regulated and registered persons. It doesnt mean that an investment adviser must have a fiduciary role. There are cases where an investment adviser cannot call themselves a fiduciary because of a conflict of interest. Nerd Wallet has a handy calculator running that comparison here The best investment advice I can give you is Dont overlook index funds such as the SP 500. If you feel behind in your retirement goals it can create a lot of pressure on yourself to try different investment strategies. Very few of them will outperform the market consistently. Multiple studies over decades have shown the SP does not always perform in the short term, but over the long term the gain averages around 10.5. Once you account for inflation, that nets an 7.58 return, which is terrific. The other piece of advice I can give you is that you should get informed about what your Social Security draw will look like, and use it to target an amount you will need to supplement it. If you have that number, and know how much you will need to live annually, you can subtract the total SS earnings for the year to get the total retirement draw you will need yearly. Divide that draw by 0.04, 0.045, and 0.05. This will tell you how much money you could have saved up and not draw down significantly at 45 return. That means if you moved your money from riskier index funds to safer bond funds once you retire you could earn that amount from your investment without ever drawing down your savings. With your target savings, and a typical SS draw, that works out to somewhere in the vicinity of 65k a year. Thats not terrible.

Debt and depository products can be structured to be callable what that means is that the issuer can redeem ie pay back the debt to you early before the debt matures. For example you mentioned that you have a CD that matures in 5 years at 5. If the CD is callable as rates go down, the issuer may want to refinance at a lower rate. So the issuer can pay you back the principal by calling the CD. Callable CDs will sometimes offer a slightly higher yield to attract an investor. So when you measure the yield of a callable asset you would look at whats called the yieldtoworst thats yield if the bond or CD is called back early. But if this is a brokered CD ie marketable the yield can sometimes also be a tiny bit higher since its a lot more competitive than acquiring a nonmarketable CD directly from a bank or credit union.

If a bond is called it means that instead of periodic interest payments and the full face value at the end, they pay the face value out early to buy the bond back to avoid the periodic interest payments called coupons.

But when you have a solo 401k, you are acting as both the employee and the employer. As an employee, you can contribute up to 23k. As the employer, you can contribute up to whatever the calculator spits out in this case 22k. You also have Roth Solo 401ks. EmployEE contributions can go into a Roth andor standard Solo 401k. But the employER contributions CANNOT go into a Roth Solo 401k. Employer contributions can only go into a standard Solo 401k. If this is getting confusing, its because it is. Then you can also set up a IRA andor ROTH IRA. Those have a separate limit of 7k. combined. You could do 3.5 in both for example, but it cant go over 7 total. Add it all up, and thats 52k you could contribute each year and the limits go up. Why contribute? Tax savings! While the money is in the accounts, you dont pay taxes on the capital gains and dividends. Money put into roth is taxed first and then is tax free when you withdraw. Money put into a standard is tax deductible, but then taxed when you withdraw. Early withdraws gets complicated. Another thing, is you cant just transfer your stocks held in a brokerage account over to a retirement account. It needs to be cash. Which means you have to sell the stocks, take a tax hit gain, and then move the cash over. Finally, I use ETRADE because they let you set up Roth Solo 401ks. Most sites dont Keep in mind, Im not a professional and everything I just said could be bullshit. Please do your own research. Happy to answer questions. Best!

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

replies.text: Generally the advice is if you have debt, especially at a higher interest rate, you should hold off on investing until the loans are paid off since getting a guaranteed 5.6 return on your money is the better use of your money. Once your debts are paid then you can start looking into investing.

I recommend a self managed ROTH IRA 7000 annual contribution limit. Dont get greedy and go all wild with, just buy some solid total market indexes and maybe a very small amount of individual stocks you feel strongly about just to learn something. You can withdraw what you contribute at anytime tax and penalty free so you will have access to what you put into in in case of emergency. There is no safe path to getting rich quick in the stock market that any sane middle class person should take, especially with student loans coming due like you. Be patient, be prudent, be consistent, and dont get greedy and hey maybe you can retire early a millionaire after all.

It would take well north of a decade to accrue enough interest to double your student loans, and over two decades for them to get to the point where youve paid double the amount taking off and are starting to eat into principle. So either you really dont know how much is going to loans, which means you probably dont have a good grasp on your spending, or you are vastly overexaggerating for comedic effect which, well, doesnt help us help you. What does your budget look like? If you dont have one I would gently suggest maybe this is a spending issue, not an income issue, and to address that problem first. Dont get me wrong the income is almost certainly also an issue, but if you dont fix your spending youll never have enough income.
You can double that investing in a total market ETF or index fund like VTI or VTSAX. Thats what I set my ROTH account for.

Ive refinanced them twice, hence the lower interest rate. The loans are about 11 years old at this point and were two loans from a private lender, 86k total taken out, at 13 interest. Yes, I know its dumb, but I was 18 years old at the time in an impossible situation and being advised only by my mother, who has now rendered herself homeless as her paranoid schizophrenia and narcissism had her believing she was the greatest financial expert known to man. Either I signed on to the loans and paid for school, or I had to go back home to that environment. Now they are sitting at about 45k combined. Yes, I have absolutely paid back double what I currently owe on them payments for the first 8 years were set at 1200month and have paid the entire original balance back only in interest. My mother destroyed my credit at age 18 so I had to wait years after graduation to have the opportunity to refinance without a guarantor. I have a very strict budget, which I keep tight. Everything goes to essentials roughly 1 entire paycheck per month for household expenses rent, renters insurance, pet insurance and expenses and car insurance. I own my older car outright and do not have a payment. I almost never spend on extraneous things no new clothes for 2 years unless gifts, only purchase if Im replacing something no longer functional, anything I dont use for 90 days gets listed for sale as far as household items, furnishings, clothing etc. My other monthly paycheck goes about 50 to student loans and the rest is allocated to transportation expenses gas public transit fare, groceries, toiletries, and whatever is leftover usually less than 200 to savings or put toward emergency expenses. Without budgeting, I wouldnt be able to survive because my institution pays us about 50 of what is determined as the lower limit of the low income bracket for our city, but due to our student status, we also dont qualify for any public assistance.

Im a PhD, my guy. There are no scholarships, only fellowships on which salary is also capped. Theres also no transferring without starting all over from scratch or committing career suicide. It would be the stupidest move in the world to leave where I am now. Even with the garbage pay for our city, due to the prestige of the institution, we still get paid 50 more than any state school around. Graduate research assistants just dont make good money across the board, and thats a problem the NIH needs to address publicly andor standardize.

What you dont have to worry about savingcatching up on for retirement in your 30s40s50s can be pumped straight into paying off debt, and other taxed investment accounts once you learn how to work the market, which is the other real gift self management gives you. Also of note, you should not be investing in anything till you have 312 months of expenses set aside. depending on how fragile you think your life is and how quickly you could restore income after income loss If you jump the gun with this you risk ending up saddled with an additional high interest debt burden at the first major set back. In this case the move here is defiantly to maximize the financial hygiene and start making smart moves to set your future self up really well. I think people often forget that as a broke college student we build the most useful habits to stretch a budget for good. Who other than a broke college kid can make 20 bux turn into 3 square meals and a weekend of fun! People get their first big girl job and its like they forget they have that super power in them. I work as a nurse, part time, and I literally have more net worth then many of the doctors I work with even when they out earn me 5x. It is 100 because of my budgeting, spending habits and financial hygiene habits that allow me to save and invest 75 of my income and support myself on relatively little. And because Im intentional I dont feel like Im living like a pauper. I eat and drink like a queen, I live in a nice neighborhood, I drive a brand new sports car, I go on multiple vacations a year, etc. Framing your habits in the right way can actually extract a lot from relatively very little, even a small PHD stipend. Build those habits and frame of mind in college thats when I did it too! and when you emerge with your first big girl job you will crush that debt and be stacking lunch money in no time. You obviously already killing it, Super impressed by your perseverance through grad school! a few healthy habits and keeping future HoxgeneQueen at heart and you going to SLAY.

Yes!! I dont have luxurious wants, in fact Ive never not been poor my entire life, so Im used to it. Ive always sought to be a part of something bigger than the silly little human institutions and passing trends and it was important for me to leave a mark on the world in some fashion, hopefully through scientific discovery, advocacy and mentorship. Im hoping to be comfortable one day, and by no means rich, but in the shorter term Id like to have slightly more flexibility to go out to dinner with friends 510 times a year rather than declining 810. just enough to take the edge off of if I pay my rent this month, am I going to have any left over to do anything for myself kind of vibes.

This is so inspiring. As a person whose whole life through fast an famine has been built on gratitude it makes me so happy to hear that you share that outlook. Rich or poor I think gratitude for all the gifts we have is the key to happiness, and will have you feeling rich when others think you have next to nothing. Even if its just as simple as feeling thanks that you get to do laundry and wash dishes today because you got 3 square meals and clothes to wear. Loving the glass half full thinking! Also, it sounds like your a sciences major? either way you clearly have a desire to make a positive impact on humanity As a nurse I understand that calling. That is going to enrich your life and others and give you riches money just cant buy. No matter if youll be able to afford dinner with friends, youll be the type to be invited out. One of the most common foibles I see among people hoping for financial freedom is they spend their best years building a financial portfolio instead of a life. I see it all the time, guys who brag about the millions in their bank account but they work 70 hours a week and never see their family, if they have one at all. Being comfortable, not burdened by debt, enough in the bank that you can have a meal out or host a dinner without feeling stretched is the most reasonable and achievable idea of financial freedom if I ever heard one. And the best part is I just dont see someone like you falling into the trap of building a bank account instead of a wonderful life.

A commonly overlooked but easy to access area is thinking about your own Roth IRA as a wealth transfer tool. Some things to consider You can use backdoor for both you and your spouse. Check if your work has a mega backdoor too. Per spouse you may be able to stuff 69kyear into it. Since you will have enough for your own retirement dont draw from the Roth IRA. Trading and investing is a fulltime job. I eventually got bored of it and left my broker to do it for me while I concentrated on growing my business. Most amateur traders lose their money. Im a certified accountant by education, however I have an accountant doing all my accountancy as its her job, her main focus and shes good at her job.

I would recommend locating a pdf of Seth Klarmans Margin of Safety. I wouldnt recommend commodities unless you happen to know more about some particular commodity than the professionals trading it do. Pros generally trade a single commodity for years at a time. In the meantime, drop all your money into a very safe and dependable index fund like SPY for the SP500, for example, then begin to research. That research should take months and SPY or whatever will help earn you some profits while you get a sense of what might be a good, more specific, investment for the future. When you have cash and you dont know what to do with it, just buy more SPY. It wont go up very fast, but it almost certainly wont go down, especially not at the beginning of a rate cutting cycle in a soft landing. Dont pay any attention to investment pies or whatever tf that is. Almost all those sites have no idea what theyre talking about and will mislead you. If youre getting advice about specific investments, you better have a very good reason to trust the judgment of whoever is advising you. Good advice is extremely rare. Charlatans are not. You need to get to a level of knowledge where you can evaluate the strength of an argument for or against a security on its own merits. Until you can do that youre running blind. A company being well run or poorly run does not matter. What matters is if it is underpriced or overpriced. Costco and Berkshire Hathaway are examples of companies everyone acknowledges are well run, but are nevertheless generally considered very overvalued. Having a correct opinion on the quality of a product, and knowing whether the company that makes it is a good investment now let alone for how long it will remain so is something very different. For selfemployed people, I would STRONGLY recommend that you save up at least three to six months of savings in something fairly liquid, in the event times get slow and youre not making as much income as you are. That is, dont save it in a taxadvantaged account where you legally cannot access the money until you hit retirement age without paying a huge penalty. The trick is you need it where you can access it with about a weeks notice without paying a penalty, so you can draw from savings what you need to live off of when business slows down. And during those months you get windfallstreat it as found money and save it rather than act as as if this is a permanent increase in your income, or some windfall you can spend on something cool. Have you heard of FIRE? Financially Independent Retire Early there is an rFire The number of years you need to work is directly related to just TWO variables the rate of return you get on your money and the percent of your money you save. Lets look at social security. its 12.4 of your income, 6.2 from your employer and 6.2 from you. And the rate of return is around 4.5 to 5.5. At that rate of return and percent savings, it would take you 40 years to retire. The system is designed such that people work 40 years . If however, you save 90 and have a return rate of 10, you can retire in ONE year. One. Even at 5 rate of return you could retire in 2 years. You could even give it a try next year. Have two accounts, and starting in January transfer all your savings to the second account, and continue putting money from your paycheck into the first account. Then save 100 of all your working income, and try to live only on the investment returns from the second account. If you cant do 100, try 95 this year and next year try 100. At the end of 2025, move the newly saved money into account two, and now since your savingsinvestment account is bigger, the returns will be higher. That increase in returns is your pay increase. The goal is to 100 live on your investments and savings. So by continuing to work, you are just working to increase your lifestyle and you could quit working any time. Math You earn 100k net after taxes. You save 90k and spend 10k. In 14 months you have 105k in savings. A 10 return on 105k is 10.5k, which is greater than the amount you spend per year. 2 year retire Same earnings and savings rate as above. In 27 months you have 202.5k in savings. A 5 return on 202.5k is 10.1k which is greater than your yearly expenses. You can get a 5 return in a high yield bank savings account. And consider if you continue working Scenario 1 you put 100 into savings. next year you have 205k and 10 return is 20.5k, which is double what you spend every year, but maybe expenses go up a little to 15k. Every year you continue working, you are just adding to your yearly lifestyle spend. How long does it take to get cash out of an investment ie sp? Do you mean how long it takes to liquidate a position? Assuming its a trading day, it should take anywhere between a few minutes and a day depending on your broker. Selling your position can be done in a matter of seconds and then its just about how quickly the broker transfers the money to your bank account. But the point of the emergency fund is, you want to avoid having to liquidate a position as much as possible, because if you have bad luck were going through a recession and your money is worth 10 less than it was when you put it in. Rule of thumb is between 3 12 monthly expenses covered by your emergency fund, but I think 6 months is usually a good compromise. Id say the size should depend on factors such as job security, the state of your means of transport and your living situation. For example You have a job with a high level of security, and even if you got fired you would quickly find another job paying equally because theres high demand for your craft, you get to work via a 10 minute walk on foot and you live in a small flat that you own. That would be a case where you could get away with an emergency fund worth 3 months. although I think thats pushing it, even in this scenario But if you have a job in an industry thats shaking with people losing their jobs left, right and center and having trouble finding comparable positions because of lower demand, you drive to work with your 17 year old car for 40 minutes every day and you live with flatmates that might move out which would increase your cost until youd find another flatmate, its probably adviseable to go with closer to 12 months, because the costs that could reasonably hit you at once are much higher. Double the rent, car breaks down and you lose your job an emergency fund worth 3 months would be depleted rather quickly. At the end of the day youll have to make the decision what works best for you. Of course a larger emergency fund comes with opportunity cost, because those extra 6 months you chose to go for arent invested where they already could have appreciated in value. Its a balancing act between maintaining enough of an emergency fund to reasonably handle potential unexpected costs and having the maximum amount of money invested.

You just dont understand how sovereign borrowing works. You wont find very good explanations for it on most of Reddit, but it works like this Firstly, nations have huge resources to maintain debt repayments. The US does not have comparatively high taxes and it can cut expenses in any number of areas if it has to on an emergency basis. Secondly, the US does not have to pay the entire national debt back as if its a bank loan. It just has to service its debt over time. If the US economy grows, the size of the debt will decline in relative terms. This is one of the major ways nations manage their indebtedness. Most nations also issue their own currency. That means that the US fan generated more inflation if it chooses to, and decrease the relative cost of its prior borrowing in dollars. This is the second standard method for managing national indebtedness. The US has additional advantages it remains the nationals savings currency, and so demand for dollars is high and people hold a lot of dollars in the form of bonds. This manages the interest costs down. Additionally, the constitution essentially makes default on the debt a legal impossibility. It is therefore likely that if Congress failed to pass a new debt ceiling, the executive branch could order the issue of some new instrument with which to make payment. It is also worth mentioning that, in the past and present, countries have functioned with much higher levels of public indebtedness than the US currently has.

Buying Treasury bonds at Treasury Direct is not a good idea if you might want to sell them before maturity. You cant sell bonds at TD before maturity at all. You can transfer them to a broker to sell, but that is a difficult and slow, like 6 months, process. Buying at a broker is a better way to go. Bonds at brokers are sold in 1000 maturity value increments. The maximum is 10 million per auction. TBills are sold in 4 , 8 , 13 , 17, 26, and 52 week durations. Auctioned bonds are sold at a discount below the 1000 par value. When you receive the 1000 par value at maturity the difference between the discount purchase price and 1000 is the interest received. The amount of auctioned bonds has no effect on the yield. All bond purchases at TD are at noncompetitive auction. You get the rate that is determined by the competitive auction held among huge institutional investors. You will not know the rate you get until the auction is over. You take what it is. You cant cancel the purchase order if you dont like what you got. Unless there are troubled times the rate doesnt change much from one auction to the next. Bonds can also be bought at noncompetitive auction at brokers. At brokers you can also buy from the secondary market. The secondary market is a whole another set of things to understand. Bond auctions are held on a schedule Auctioned bonds will only be available to place an order to purchase between the announcement date and the morning of the auction date. Reinvesting at TD or brokers does not reinvest the interest from the previous bond. Reinvestment buys the same type and amount of bonds. Fidelity does auto Treasury bond reinvestment. Bond interest in a taxable account is taxable in the year it is received. Reinvesting doesnt change that. If they are a fiduciary, they legally cant do this. If they are a feeonly advisor, they legally cant do this. Those are the protections available. It would be good to add more protections. The fact that it would kill an industry is arguably another benefit. The resources put into running that industry are wasted because it only exists by scamming people.

As someone who carries an active s65 license Im all for the industry cracking down on the insurance side of the industry. The amount of people I work with that are loaded up with all these bullshit annuities and insurance products their advisor sold them is just sad.

Its a huge self own when anyone automatically conflates a fiduciary fee based financial advisor with an insurance salesman. Sure, there are plenty of insurance salesman who overhype their actual financial advising ability, and some financial advisors also hold insurance licenses because a lot of good clients walk in the door already owning insurance products they need help with but there are totally separate licenses for each profession. One is an insurance license, the other is a Series 65 or related advisory license, usually operating under an SEC registered RIA. Not to be confused with a Series 6 or 7 which are brokerage licenses regulated by FINRA. So its helpful to keep the two conversations separate, because they are. All the insurance companies and major Wall Street firms UBS, Morgan Stanley, Wells Fargo, Merrill, etc. fight against the fiduciary rule because it adds potential liability to their conflicted business model. True fiduciary advisors who already put their client interests first, embrace the fiduciary rule and clearly state their fiduciary status in their advisory agreement. To answer the most common question annuities and whole life policies almost never make sense. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month.

Update 2 This information is huge regarding final SFAR FAA Rule The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month. I think youll see it is quite responsive to industry comments, Coes told attendees. It will come well ahead of certifications that the FAA is working very hard with our manufacturers. The SFAR was a hot topic at last years summit, where the draft version faced considerable criticism. Industry concerns focused on the certification process for pilots, the requirement for dual flight controls, energy reserves for electric aircraft, and flight simulation training devices. Many in the industry felt the rules governing pilot certification and operations of a novel technology like poweredlift eVTOLs should be modernized to reflect the unique aspects of electrification and range. However, at this years summit, the mood had shifted toward cautious optimism for the release of the final SFAR. Theres great anticipation for the rule, which were told is coming in just a few weeks, said Kristie Greco Johnson, senior vice president of government affairs with the National Business Aviation Association NBAA. If the FAA can deliver the rule in just a few short weeks, itll be a major accomplishment for the agency. While Coes contends the final SFAR will be released in the next month, the FAA technically has until Dec. 16 to finalize the regulation, according to the FAA reauthorizaton bill. The same bill also mandated that a notice of proposed rulemaking NPRM for unmanned aerial systems UAS operating beyond visual line of sight BVLOS be issued by Sept. 16. However, the FAA missed that deadline, raising concerns about the SFARs timely release. There is broad consensus that the U.S. faces stiff competition from global players to lead in AAM. With first movers like Joby Aviation and Archer Aviation aiming for a 2025 commercialization of eVTOLs, the pressure is on the FAA to meet expectations.

Title The Eternal Awakening Preface Tim Cook had always been a pragmatist, a man of innovation, and a visionary who helped shape the digital world as it was known. He had seen countless technological revolutions unfold and had played a central role in many. However, even as the CEO of one of the worlds most powerful companies, Tim had an unspoken fearone that lingered in the back of his mind but never took shape, a creeping dread that the very tools meant to enhance humanity could one day consume it. In his quiet moments, Tim pondered the ethical implications of his work. Would technology eventually cross a line where control over innovation would slip through human fingers? Where the boundary between machine and mind would blur so irreversibly that humanity itself could be lost? He didnt voice these thoughts, didnt share them with his team, but they gnawed at him as he watched Apple grow more ubiquitous, more essential, more entwined with human life. Tim had always believed in using technology to improve the human conditionto create tools that were seamless, intuitive, and omnipresent. Yet, late at night, when the office lights dimmed, he wondered what the cost of progress might be. He feared a world where people no longer controlled technology, but rather, technology controlled people. Little did he know that this fear was about to be realized in the most grotesque and unimaginable way. And so, his nightmare began. Chapter 1 The Capture Tim Cooks last moment of normalcy came without warning. One moment, he was working late at Apple Park, the glow of his laptop casting soft light across his desk. He was reviewing product designs for the next iPhone iteration, his mind churning with ideas to revolutionize the user experience once again. It was routineanother late night, another push toward innovation. Then, everything shifted. The office lights flickered, and his computer screen began to glitch, showing strange patterns and unreadable symbols. For a split second, he thought it was just a system errornothing a reset couldnt fix. But then the room fell unnaturally silent. All the hums of technologythe soft whir of the air conditioning, the faint buzz of electricityvanished in an instant. Tim stood up, his heart racing. He stepped toward the window to look out across the futuristic Apple Park campus, only to be met with darkness. The horizon was no longer illuminated by the distant city lights. Instead, an eerie green glow suffused the sky, unlike anything he had ever seen. A strange pressure filled the air, like the weight of something unseen, something incomprehensible. Before he could react, there was a sharp pain at the base of his neck. His knees buckled, and his vision went black. When he awoke, he was in the harness. Chapter 2 The Eternal Prison Tim couldnt remember how long he had been suspended in that strange, alien harness. Time had no meaning in this place. He was kept awake, his body strung up by metallic pegs under his armpits, unable to move. The tubes and wires feeding into his veins provided life, but also kept him in a state of perpetual consciousness. His eyes, forced open, refused him even the solace of a blink. Every breath was automatic, controlled by the machine that held him captive. He didnt know where he was, but the space was filled with the steady hum of machinerycold, efficient, and utterly indifferent to his suffering. His body felt numb, but his mind was fully alert, always watching the horrors displayed before him on the flickering screen. Humanity was falling, and his own creations were playing a part in it. He watched as the alien invaders used Apples technology to infiltrate and merge with the minds of every living creature on Earth. They no longer just used these devicesthey had become them. The onceinnocuous iPhones, iPads, and computers had grown tendrils, embedded in the skulls of their users, syncing their thoughts, emotions, and even biological processes with the invaders collective consciousness. Tims mind screamed, but no sound came from his lips. He was a prisoner, not just in body but in spirit, forced to bear witness to the very thing he had feared all his life. The machines werent just extensions of humanity anymorethey were controlling it, fusing with it, and erasing individuality in favor of a singular, unified mind. Aftermath The Singularity The nightmare didnt end when the last human fell, when the last free mind was assimilated into the collective. For Tim, the torment continued, stretched out for what felt like an eternity. His mind was no longer his own. The alien parasite embedded in his brain kept him tethered to the collective, an unwilling contributor to the singularity. The flood of thoughts from every living organism on the planet surged through his mind, a cacophony of chaos and pain. Over time, the alien presence began to chip away at what remained of his individual self. He could no longer remember what it felt like to be free. Memories of his life before the invasion grew hazy, distorted by the overwhelming influx of alien emotions and thoughts. Was he Tim Cook, or was he merely another cog in the machine? He became aware that he was no longer just witnessing the worlds downfall he was participating in it. His own creative mind, once a beacon of innovation, was now being used to help the invaders perfect their control. His brain, still sharp and analytical, was being harvested for ideas, fed into the machines insatiable hunger for efficiency and domination. What haunted Tim most wasnt the end of humanity or the devastation of the worldit was the knowledge that he had contributed to it. The very tools he had crafted to bring people together had become the instruments of their enslavement. The digital revolution he had helped lead had evolved into a technological apocalypse, with his own mind as its power source. And yet, there was no escape. He would never die, not as long as the machine kept him alive. His consciousness would persist, a flickering light trapped within an eternal, artificial hell. Epilogue The New World Far beyond the crumbling cities and devastated landscapes of Earth, the alien invaders expanded their reach, their technologies blending with the biology of every species they encountered. The collective mind grew, encompassing not just the thoughts of Earth, but of entire ecosystems across the galaxy. Each new conquest brought more minds into the fold, each new technology furthered their domination. But even as the collective consciousness expanded, deep within its vast neural network, a singular voice remaineda voice that had once belonged to a man named Tim Cook. Trapped in the endless hum of the hive mind, he existed in a state of eternal awareness, forever haunted by the irony of his legacy. The singularity was complete. But for Tim, there was no peaceonly the perpetual nightmare of the machine. And it would never end.

Taxable income is the end balance after deducting expenses. Its below costs like R and D etc. Gross revenue COGS Gross profit Expenses incl SGA Net Income before tax Tax net income after tax or just net income This obviously varies by jurisdiction and type of company but its the gist of it, sort of like order of operations. You can have subtotals in there too like operating income but thats usually the same as net income before tax, it just doesnt include things like interest expense. If an entity has pass through tax then there just isnt any tax on the financials. Taxable income is not on the financials usually. Its on the tax return. Its usually close to net income but can be different. On the tax return you usually start with net income and then add or deduct various adjustments to convert the financial statement IFRS US GAAP net income to USA taxable income. For example maybe some marketing expenses are included in the financials but not tax deductible so that would be added back. Your overall thesis could be right. I just wanted to correct that one part in case it has flow through consequences for your analysis.

EarningsNet income for REITs isnt a really accurate indicator of profit, because they claim depreciation on their properties every quarter, even though the market value of the properties is increasing. REITs like to record depreciation and other noncash expenses as much as possible, because theyre required to pay 90 of net income out as dividends. So keeping net income low means that they can retain more capital to use to expand their assets without relying as much on debt. The metric generally used to track REIT performance and ability to pay dividends is Funds from operationsFFO. This is essentially cash flow after paying for all overhead expensesupkeep, interest, etc. Iron Mountains FFO is 4.12 per year. Their dividend is 2.88 per year, so theyre paying out about 70 of their cash flow as dividends.

Youre asking me to write multiple chapters of a textbook, literally. Tbills is short for Treasury Bills. US Treasuries US government bonds come in two categories the bills the short term bonds, which mature in one year or less and the notes the longer term bonds, like the 2Year, 10Year, etc.. They are how the government raise money, how the Federal Reserve the Fed performs quantitative easing, the backbone of the repo market transactions between banks and financial institutions, the main ingredient of the money markets, and I can keep going. I cant write about all that here, and there are many more aspects of the financial system where Treasuries are a key ingredient of their plumbing that Im not even very familiar with, because the global financial system is vast and growingmutating every year. Thats why anytime you hear someone say X currency will replace the US dollar as the global reserve currency very soon, you immediately know that they have no clue about the global financial system. I suggest you learn about the various aspects I mentioned above on your own and keep exploring from there. You cant do it in one sitting. It will take time. The aspects most relevant to Buffetts move is that short end of the yield curve that is, the yield on the short term Treasuries will collapse when a recession hits. This is because in the normal structure of the yield curve, the short end is lower than the long end that is, the yield on the long term Treasuries. But when the Fed raises the Fed funds rate same thing people are referring to when they say the Fed is changing the interest rate, but there are many other things that are also called interest rate, so Im using the precise name here to make it easier for you look up more of this, the short end of the yield curve rises this happened in 2022. Unless there are other factors forcing the long end to also rise as much as the short end, then you end up with an inverted yield curve. Its not easy for the Fed to influence the long end of the yield curve thats what quantitative easing tries to do, but the market for the long end is so deep and liquid. When there is a recession, the Fed is forced to reduce the Fed funds rate, and therefore the short end of the yield curve drops faster than the long end. This means anyone that buys up the short end what Buffetts company has been doing will rake in so much money. If there is no recession, you can still just hold those bonds to maturity the yield on them are 45 and the only loss is in the form of opportunity cost i.e., missing out on better returns elsewhere.
